title: What Vaccines Really Cause Autism? Separating Fact from Fiction
author: Dr Nao
description: Learn the truth about vaccines and autism. Nao Medical offers comprehensive healthcare services, including urgent care, primary care, telehealth, and more. Book an appointment today.
cleaned_text: There has been a lot of controversy surrounding vaccines and their potential link to autism. However, the overwhelming scientific consensus is that vaccines do not cause autism. In fact, numerous studies have been conducted over the years, and none have found a causal link between vaccines and autism. So, what vaccines have been falsely linked to autism? The most commonly cited vaccine is the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine. This is due to a now-debunked study that was published in 1998, which claimed that the MMR vaccine caused autism. The study has since been retracted, and the author has been discredited. Other vaccines that have been falsely linked to autism include the flu vaccine and the hepatitis B vaccine. However, there is no scientific evidence to support these claims. The Importance of Vaccines Despite the false claims about vaccines and autism, it is important to remember that vaccines are crucial for protecting public health. Vaccines have been instrumental in eradicating diseases such as smallpox and polio, and they continue to prevent countless illnesses and deaths every year. By getting vaccinated, you not only protect yourself but also those around you who may be more vulnerable to disease, such as young children, the elderly, and people with weakened immune systems.
